Title:
Species clarification of the medicinal wood-inhabiting fungi
of Phylloporia (Hymenochaetales, Basidiomycota) in China
Abstract:
Species of Phylloporia, a genus of wood-inhabiting fungi,
possess strong relationships with their host genera. Basidiocarps of
Phylloporia have been used as medicines in folklore mainly in Shandong
Province, China. However, although the species diversity of Phylloporia
has been extremely explored worldwide recently, the species identity of
the medicinal basidiocarps is still unconfirmed. In this study, we
sampled basidiocarps of Phylloporia from the host genera recorded in
medicinal studies. On the basis of morphological and phylogenetic
evidence, it is clarified that Phylloporia lonicerae is the most widely
used medicinal species of this genus, P. fontanesiae is rarely used, and
P. pulla is potentially used. The taxonomical status of these three
species are briefly discussed, and P. lonicerae and P. pulla originally
described outside China are described with illustrations. This
clarification is crucial for medicinal studies and potential industry
development of this kind of fungal resources.
